Reasoning: **Analyzing Square Joker mechanics**

I’m trying to sort through the mechanics of the Square Joker, specifically its "gains +4 chips if played hand has exactly 4 cards" feature. It seems like this chip gain is separate and permanent, possibly scaling with its current value. But I'm uncertain about how it interacts with the current hand and if it adds chips each time. I'm revisiting the mechanics in Balatro to clarify if it gives chips more than once per hand. There’s definitely some confusion here!
**Clarifying Square Joker mechanics**

I'm looking at the Square Joker's mechanics again. It gives +4 chips when the hand has exactly 4 cards, and this bonus seems to be permanent, contributing to each hand's score. The holo edition adds a +10 multiplier, but I'm a bit puzzled about how these multipliers interact. It looks like I should prioritize adding multipliers before applying any multiplication effects to maximize gains. Arranging the +mult jokers earlier and having the duo and order multipliers at the end feels like the best strategy.
**Understanding chip and multiplier interactions**

I'm analyzing the roles of various jokers in the game. The Blue Joker adds chips but doesn't affect multipliers, so their order isn't crucial. The Square Joker does provide a +mult bonus, especially in holo form, and should ideally be placed before x multipliers to maximize gains. DNA has an ability related to single cards but doesn't provide scoring benefits, so I wonder if it can be used to copy a powerful card. For the boss battle, I think I’ll need a couple of hands to reach the required score.
**Strategizing for the boss battle**

I’m considering the challenges for the boss due to the face-down draw, yet I can still utilize straights and pairs. To maximize scoring, I think I should order the jokers strategically: putting the Square Joker before Duo and Order, along with its holographic +10 multiplier and potential chip bonus. The best order looks like DNA, Blue, Square, Duo, and Order. Since the Blue Joker is for chips, its placement isn't crucial. Reasoning: **Calculating full house score**

I have three 10s and two queens, which gives me a full house (10s over queens) when I play 10♥, 10♣, 10♦, Q♠, and Q♦. My base chips are 65 with a base multiplier of 6. Each 10 and queen contributes chips based on their rank, so I calculate this as 50 from the full house and additional chips from the Blue Joker and Square. Finally, after considering the multiplier, my total ends up being 7264 chips!
**Calculating total score options**

I need a total of 10,000 chips across five hands. It’s challenging because a straight with Order could give me 7,056 chips at level 1, while the full house is around 7,264. I’m considering if we could win with one hand by combining a straight and a pair, but that doesn’t seem possible. If I hit a flush at level 2, I might get around 3,200 chips, which still falls short of 10,000. So, I need to strategize more!
**Exploring scoring possibilities**

I’m trying to find the best scoring strategy, weighing options like a straight with a multiplier of three or a pair with a multiplier of two. A full house could also work with a multiplier of six. The straight has a base multiplier of four, but the chip values can be tricky. The rank values are straightforward: 10, J, Q, K, and A all have specific chip values. I want to maximize my chips, focusing on high-value cards with face cards adding significant worth!
**Calculating full house and four of a kind**

# Available Commands
The possible commands in Balatro are all composed of a single word specifying the action, followed by any necessary positional arguments, which are lists of integers.
Note: all position arguments are 1-indexed.

The following commands are available in your current game state.
use_consumable <consumeable_position> <target_card_position1> <target_card_position2> ... <target_card_positionN> - Use a consumeable from the consumeables section. The first position argument is the position within your consumables inventory of the consumable you'd like to use. Subsequent position arguments specify the cards in hand that the consumeable will be used on, if that consumeable requires targets.
sell_consumable <consumeable_position> - Sell a consumeable from the consumeables section.
rearrange_jokers <joker1> <joker2> ... <jokerN> - Rearrange the list of currently owned jokers. Every index in the list of current jokers must be present, i.e. if there are 5 jokers, the indices 1-5 must be present.
sell_joker <joker_position> - Sell a joker from the jokers section.
play <card1> <card2> ... <card5> - Play the selected cards and draw new ones from the deck. You may play up to 5 cards at a time. If you play a hand, you must also respond with the intended hand type you think you are playing, and an estimate of the number of chips you think you will earn from the hand. Use the results of previous hands played to inform your estimate.
discard <card1> <card2> ... <card5> - Discard the selected cards and draw new ones from the deck. You may discard up to 5 cards at a time.
rearrange_hand <card1> <card2> ... <cardN> - Rearrange the hand of cards. Every index in the list of current cards must be present, i.e. if there are 5 cards, the indices 1-5 must be present.
